Navigation
Name Tutorial/Basic
Synopsis What you need to know to do basic programming in Rascal
Details Values IO Expressions Types Patterns Data Functions Statements Backtracking Query Templates Transformation
Description The Basic level has the following lessons:
  • Values: What does the data look like that you can manipulate in Rascal and how to type it in?
  • IO:
  • Expressions:
  • Types:
  • Patterns:
  • Data:
  • Functions:
  • Statements:
  • Backtracking:
  • Query:
  • Templates:
  • Transformation:
In all lessons we explain Rascal by example by showing the Rascal prompt with an example program, statement or expression. Rascal will compute the result and print both the type of the value and the value itself, or ok if there is no result. Each lesson ends with a number of questions to find out if you get it.
Examples How to print Hello World: 
rascal>import IO;
ok
rascal>println("Hello World!");
Hello World!
ok
How to assign a value to a variable 
rascal>x = 42;
int: 42

Questions
Question [Import]. Which library needs to be imported from the standard library to be able to call println:




Question [2]. assign a variable
Fill in 
x = ;
and make the following true:
1 + x == 2;

Question [3]. do not forget the semicolon
Fill in 
x = 1
and make the following true:
x == 1;
